timeline.bodyText:
Are you sure of this code? As far as I can see this code will double the size of samples as soon as a DatasetNotSeparableException is thrown (regardless if it is the first attempt or similar) and again and again until the generated dataset is separable or that noOfRetries will be 0.
Is it the logic you want? Do you expect it is never (or almost never) possible that a new sample of the same size will produce a separated dataset?
timeline.author: danielezonca

replies.bodyText:
Yes, this is the intent. It might still happen that re-generating a new dataset will produce a separable dataset on a second run. I was however thinking in terms of the cost of this retry mechanism in terms of resources, therefore I was thinking that perhaps it's better to "spend" resources (generating perturbed data + computing outputs for each) when you have a higher likelihood of succeeding in the task of getting a separable dataset. That's why I set to do both increased sampling and increased perturbation size.
But maybe we can make a compromise and not just double the sample size, but rather increase it by n/100 on each retry where n is the configured number of retries (so that you end up with a doubled dataset size on the final retry, rather than with a n times bigger dataset).
Same goes for the number of perturbations we can increase it more "slowly" and get it at half the no. of features by the last retry.

this is better implemented in #530 where the depth at which the stability is checked is made configurable.
So I would leave it as it is for now, and then switch to that metric within #530.
